Biofouling and scaling are commonly encountered bottlenecks in large and small scale installations ofmembrane technology for surface-,waste- or seawater treatment. The phenomena can pose persistent operational challenge with substantial economic impacts if they are left unresolved. Effort has been made to reduce the tendency of these detrimental phenomena by improving membrane properties, optimizing operational conditions as well as establishing reliable pretreatment of the feed water. This review places a main focus on the recent advances of low biofouling and scaling thin film composite (TFC) membranes that are incorporated with different types of nanomaterials. In this contribution, the biofouling and scaling phenomena and their negative effects on TFC membranes are first discussed. The recent studies on the preparation of low biofouling and anti-scaling TFC membrane using different nanomaterials are then critically summarized. Current challenges to enhance membrane long-term stability, reliability, and cost efficiency are also highlighted. The applications of nanomaterials inmembrane desalination are anticipated to improve resistance properties of TFCmembranes against biofouling and scaling and further foster the innovation of sustainable membrane desalination technology.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In the 21st century, the most crucial problem afflicting people around the world is global water scarcity. The rapid growth in population and economy has resulted in significant increase in the demand of drinking water quantity and quality, leading to a catastrophic water shortage particularly in arid andwater-stressed region areas. As a result, the present surface water resources will no longer be sufficient to meet the future needs of mankind.
One of the solutions for addressing this globalwater shortage issue is to implement the membrane technologies. Of the membrane technologies used in the water and wastewater treatments, the market for nanofiltration (NF), reverse osmosis (RO) and forward osmosis (FO) is currently witnessing expedited growth and the totalmarket is expected

to continuously increase over the next years. In the current market, NF, RO and FO membranes are generally made via interfacial polymerization technique. Using this technique, thin film composite (TFC) membranes that consist of an ultrathin barrier layer formed over a microporous substrate supported by a non-woven polyester can be produced [1]. Owing to ultrathin selective layer, TFC membranes have emerged as excellent candidates in awide variety of separation applications, particularly in the seawater desalination. However, one of the main problems arising upon the operation of the membrane units is the membrane fouling, which seriously hampers the application of membrane technologies.
Of differentmembrane foulingphenomena, biofouling is a termused to describe all instances of fouling where biologically active organisms such as microorganisms, fungi, viruses and excreted extracellular biopolymers are involved [2]. Biofouling of the surface of TFC membranes is a commonly encountered problem that can dramatically diminish the treatment process efficiency and cost effectiveness, especially in the case dealing with the wastewater that contains substantial amount

of microorganisms and nutrients. Membrane biofouling is initiated by irreversible adhesion of one or more bacteria to the membrane surface followed by fast growth and multiplication of microorganisms in the presence of feed water nutrients [3–5], which eventually result in the formation of biofilm on the membrane surface [3].
As mentioned in the work of Kochkodan and Hilal [2], typical adverse effects of membrane biofouling include (i) a reduction inmembrane water flux due to establishment of biofilm on membrane surface, (ii) an increase in solute concentration polarization accompanied by lower solute rejection (in RO and NF membranes), (iii) an increase in the module differential pressure (ΔP), (iv) biodegradation and/or biodeterioration of the membrane polymer, (v) establishment of concentrated populations of primary or secondary human pathogens on membrane surfaces and (vi) increased energy requirements due to the higher pressure requirements to overcome the biofilm resistance and the flux decline. Due to the reduction of salt rejection and flux caused by biofilm [6,7], biofouling is a serious obstacle in membrane filtration and treatment processes, particularly for RO. Several methods have been established to overcome membrane biofouling and most of these methods are based on the enhancement of antimicrobial and anti-adhesion properties [8–10]. The antimicrobial property improves bacteria lysis, while the anti-adhesion property increases the adhesion resistance of the surface against bacterial attachment.
Another serious problem faced by TFC membranes is the scale formation at the membrane surface resulted from the increased concentration of inorganic salts beyond their solubility limits. This, as a consequence, results in severe inorganic salt precipitation onto the membranes [11,12]. The term ‘membrane scaling’ is commonly referred to the formation of deposits of inverse-solubility salts such as CaCO3, CaSO4·2H2O, BaSO4, SrSO4, Ca3(PO4)2, Fe(OH)2 and Al(OH)3 on the membrane surface. The mechanisms of the inorganic scale formation have been previously described by Schafer et al. [13] and Al-Amoudi et al. [14]. Schafer et al. [13] attributed the membrane scaling to two main factors, i.e. filter cake formation and surface blockage. The former involves crystalline particles formed in the bulk of the solution to create a thick but not very coherent layer and deposited on themembrane surface, whereas with respect to mechanism of surface blockage, the deposits on the membrane surface are more coherent and continuous, which can grow with time, laterally and normally to the surface, and the flux would steadily decline as the deposits might inhibit the water permeate through the membrane surface. Al-Amoudi and Lovitt [14] on the other hand, identified that the membrane scaling phenomenon is influenced by various parameters such as temperature, pH, flow velocity, types of pretreatment, salt concentration, membrane type and its materials and other metal ions. They concluded that the surface scaling might be reduced, provided that the solubility of the ions salt is less than its equilibrium solubility.
In regard to this, there is an urgent need to search for other innovative and sustainable approaches to mitigate the impact of scaling and biofouling in membrane-based technology particularly in desalination process. Currently there is a consensus in research that the membrane fouling is mainly determined by undesirable formation of deposits on membrane top layer surfaces, influenced by the membrane surface properties, physical and chemical interaction between the membrane and the foulants. Therefore, one of themain strategies towards reducing membrane fouling is to incorporate different nanomaterials into the TFC membrane top layer, which plays a vital role in both the fouling interactions and the membrane separation.
To date, a number of advances have beenmade in the areas of material science for the development of desalination membranes based on the incorporation of nanoparticles and nanocomposites fabrication. The different types of nanomaterials have conferred almost unlimited technological benefits in terms of the adaptation and optimization of new generationmembrane for the existing desalination plants. Exciting findings and breakthroughs have been constantly made through the incorporation of conventional nanomaterials such as metal oxides, silica,

zeolites as well as the emerging carbon-based nanomaterials such as carbon nanotube (CNT) and graphene to introduce new degrees of free domain to the desalination membrane design [15,16]. The previously published reviews devoted to the preparation and properties of composite polymer membranes were mainly focused on the different surface modification techniques and the prevention methods [2, 17–20]. Therefore, the aim of this review is to comprehensively provide the recent scientific and technological advances in the development of TFC membrane that incorporates with nanomaterials. The causes of fouling phenomenon and the surface modification via different nanomaterials would be critically summarized in terms of their water flux and salt rejection. The current challenges to enhance the mitigation of biofouling and scaling effects of TFC membrane and foster the development of sustainable membrane desalination technologies are also highlighted.

sections.heading: 2.1. Parameters causing scaling and its influence on the TFC membrane performance
sections.text: Scaling is one of the major challenges that hinders the full-scale operation of membrane desalination. In TFC membrane desalination processes, a supersaturated condition is mainly caused by the pressure or temperature changes that lead to nucleation and growth of crystals in the feed solution and to themembrane surface [21,22]. Numerous studies have shown thatmembrane fouling in the presence of inorganicmaterials can be influenced by surface properties and characteristics of feed solution including ionic strength and pH as well as the system operating conditions including pressure, temperature, flow velocity and concentration polarization (CP).

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Effect of concentration polarization
sections.text: Concentration polarization is themost important factor contributing to scale formationon themembrane surface. Thepermeation process allows only water molecules to pass throughwhile retaining non-volatile salts, causing an increase in salt concentration near the membrane interface. This phenomenon is referred to as CP. It has been reported that the operating pressure plays major role in influencing the CP. At low operating pressure, the initial flux and the CP ratio remain low and the surface crystallization decreases as the operating pressure goes down. Lin et al. [22] examined the effect of operating pressure on CaSO4 scaling at constant crossflow velocity of 0.04m/s. It was reported that the flux was much lower at pressure of 966 kPa compared to the flux at 345 kPa. This is due to increased degree of CP and osmotic pressure at the membrane surface. As compared with TFC RO membrane, TFC FO membrane presents less fouling as FO membrane normally requires extremely low pressures to operate. However, FOmembrane encounters another problem, i.e. internal concentration polarization (ICP), which does not present in RO [23–28].

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Effect of flow velocity
sections.text:
With an increase in feed flow velocity, both heat and mass transfer coefficients would be enhanced. Also, more turbulence in flow is occurred at high velocity, minimizing concentration polarization. Eric et al. [29] reported that the increasing cross-flow velocity significantly decreased fouling. Lin et al. [22] found that at low cross-flow velocity of 0.0032 m/s, enhanced nucleation and subsequent crystallization at the membrane surface (CaSO4 cake formation) as a result of higher degree of concentration polarization increased the degree of CaSO4 supersaturation on the membrane surface, which led to severe scaling problem and higher flux decline (see Fig. 1). However, at higher crossflow velocity of 0.04 m/s, a longer filtration steady time was required for the system, due to the much greater shear flow on the concentrate side, which in turn reduced the residence time available for CaSO4 salt

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Effect of temperature
sections.text: Temperature plays a significant effect on scaling since the solubilities of common foulants are highly temperature dependent. Specifically, the solubility of individual salt may be either positively or adversely correlated with temperature. For example, the solubility of sodium chloride increases with temperature, whereas that of calcium carbonate, magnesium hydroxide, and calcium phosphate decreases with temperature [30]. Several studies have focused on the impact of the temperature difference on water flux and salt rejection across TFC membranes. For instances, Phuntsho et al. [30] and Xie et al. [31] examined the water flux performance for FO application. It was found that water flux was significantly increased by increasing draw solution temperature. This is due to the decreased draw solution viscosity coupled with increased water molecules diffusivity at higher solution temperature.

sections.heading: 2.1.4. Effect of pH
sections.text: pH plays a dominant role in scale formation in the TFC membrane system. This is attributed to the influence of pH towards the zeta potential (ZP) of membrane, imposing different charges on the functional groups of the membrane material and of the molecules in solution [31, 32]. The membrane surface tends to display negatively charge, i.e. negative ZP, when the solution pH is higher than its isoelectric point (IEP) (neutral) and vice versa. Childress and Elimelech [32] found that waterfluxwas enhanced and salt rejectiondecreased at the IEP ofmembrane pore, primarily due to decreased electrostatic repulsion and increased pore size. Thereafter, Schäfer et al. [33] also reported that a higher negative ZP could lead to a higher salt rejection owing to an enhanced electrostatic interaction between the negatively charged membrane surface and charged solutes.

sections.heading: 2.1.5. Effect of ionic strength
sections.text:
According to the literature, when the concentration of salt is increased, it would cause the ionic activity of salt ions to increase, resulting in a decrease of solubility and increasing scaling fouling on membrane surface [34]. With increasing feed concentration, the cations on the membrane surface are increased, causing the effect of Donnan exclusion to diminish. This causes the salts to precipitate onmembrane surface [35]. Similarly, Eric et al. [29] reported that the decrease in ionic strength significantly suppressed the membrane fouling. The increased ionic strength in the solutionwas also reported to decrease solution solubility, resulting in more severe scaling fouled on membrane surface [29].

2.2. Surface modification of TFC membrane using nanoparticles
Nanomaterials such as zeolite, silica, multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) and titanium dioxide (TiO2) nanoparticles have been incorporated into the polyamide (PA) layer to enhance the membrane antiscaling properties [36–40]. The incorporated nanoparticles are evidenced to provide a direct path for water transport and modify the membrane network structure, thereby increasing water permeability and anti-scaling properties. For instance, Emadzadeh et al. [41,42] made the first attempt to embed commercial TiO2 nanoparticles into themicroporous substrate of the compositemembrane via direct blending method for FO process. In FO process, the substrate layer plays an important role for the membrane performance as both top PA selective layer and bottom substrate are simultaneously contacted with aqueous solutions during filtration process, but of different osmotic pressures. From the normalized flux results shown in Fig. 2, it was reported that 92% of flux recovery could be obtained by the membrane incorporated with TiO2 in comparison to 79% shown by the control TFC membrane after 30-min water rinsing. Better foulant removal of the new membrane is ascribed to the enhanced hydrophilicity of the substrate membrane, which resulted in weaker interaction between the membrane and the foulant. Their works showed that instead of modifying PA layer properties, improving the microporous substrate properties by embedding TiO2 nanoparticles could also be an effective approach to enhance FO performance by minimizing the effect of internal concentration polarization which leads to lower scaling effect on the TiO2modified PA layer.
In addition to TiO2, TFC membranes embedded with zeolite nanoparticles have also been explored by several researchers owing to unique properties of zeolites such asmolecular sieving and competitive adsorption and diffusion. These positive features are able to offer an alternative for the enhancement of membrane anti-scaling ability. In desalination, what makes zeolite membranes a viable option is their unique cation exchange behavior in which the dissolved cations can be easily removed from water by exchanging with cations on the exchangeable sites of the zeolite membranes [18,39]. Lind et al. [44] compared the anti-fouling performance of pure PA TFC, zeolite-PA TFC and commercial membrane. They reported that the zeolite-PA TFC membrane that post-treated with NaHCO3 could significantly increase the salt permeability coefficients of control TFC and commercialmembrane.

Similar findings were also experienced by Fathizadeh et al. [36], where the self-synthesized nanozeolite-A was incorporated into PA to enhance the anti-scaling ability of the composite membranes. Excellent membrane performance was observed for the nanocomposite membrane containing about 0.2% (w/v) nano-NaX zeolite, 0.1% (w/v) trimesoyl and 2% (w/v) m-phenylenediamine which its flux was 1.8 times higher than the flux value of the bare PA membrane without any change in salt rejection. The high hydrophilicity of NaX has rendered improved interfacial free energy, surface roughness and contact angle in the newly synthesized composite membrane. The improvement in membrane surface properties has led to enhanced scaling mitigation of the modified PA layer and higher water flux performance.
Saleh and Gupta [38] embedded alumina oxide (Al2O3) nanoparticles into PA membrane via in-situ interfacial polymerization technique. The experimental results indicated that compared to the control membrane, the modified PA membrane always demonstrated the higher water permeability and salt rejection as shown in Fig. 3. The authors

Nevertheless, one drawback of direct blending method is that the embedded nanomaterials tend to be buried under bulk polymer which is likely to reduce the positive effect of nanomaterials in PA selective layer. Hence, Tiraferri and his co-workers [45,46] made an attempt to bind the TFC membrane surface with various functionalized nanomaterials via simple dip coating method. Their results showed that the appearance of these nanomaterials on the membrane surface could enhance the antifouling properties of TFC membrane and further render the membrane surface with higher wettability and hydrophilicity.
The fascinating physical properties of CNTs have opened a great number of potential applications for this unique material. One of the most important structural properties that merits CNTs as favorable nanomaterial for desalination is their ability to reject dissolved ions while enablingwatermolecules to pass through. In addition, theminute pore diameter can create additional energy barriers for the ions rejection [48]. Zhao et al. [47] incorporated MWCNTs into PA polymer membrane. As shown in Fig. 4, the flux decline of the PA/MWNTsmembrane was remarkably lower than that of neat PA membrane, demonstrating that the PA/MWNTsmembrane could effectively reduce inorganic fouling. The improved antifouling property against Ca(HCO3)2 was mainly attributed to the enhanced electrostatic repulsion between charged membrane surface and the inorganic ions.
Other carbon based materials such as graphene and graphene oxide (GO) have also been studied to mitigate the membrane fouling tendency. Graphene is a two-dimensional nanomaterial comprising of a twodimensional sheet of carbon atoms arranged in a hexagonal configuration. As mentioned previously, current membrane desalination techniques use conventional membranes that have specific water flux and rejection, but advances in material science offer enhancements to these properties. Recently, a breakthrough in molecular dynamic studies revealed that graphene can function as a thin barrier for efficient water purification while achieving ultra-high water flux [49,50]. The unique properties that graphene sheets offer such as the high surface area and excellent mechanical strength encouraged researchers to look into graphene as a nanomaterial that can possibly replace conventional membrane materials [51]. Cohen-Tanugi and Grossman [49] showed that permeation of water across the graphenemembrane could achieve ultra-high flux of 1041 L/m2 h·bar with zero salt permeation, owing to the specific pore size and pore functionalization of the GO membrane. sections.heading: 3.1. Parameters influencing biofouling and performance of TFC membrane
sections.text:
The attachment of bacterial cells to the membrane surface is the main cause contributing biofilm fouling. In environment with high concentration of nutrients (e.g. discharged industrial wastewater or polluted seawater), the number of attached bacterial cells would be increased
Please cite this article as: C.S. Ong, et al., Nanomaterials for biofouling and lination (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.desal.2016.01.007
which facilitates the formation of biofilm on the TFCmembrane surface [65]. Biofilm formation could partially or completely block the pores of TFCmembrane, reducing diffusive transport and decreasing the permeation flux. There are many factors affecting cellular attachment. These include the characteristics of feed, pH and temperature. Several surface characteristics of membranes such as hydrophobic/hydrophilic properties, membrane surface charge (zeta potential) and roughness are also critical to biofouling because they dictate the interaction betweenmembrane and the bacterial cells.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Effect of temperature
sections.text:
Temperature imparts significant effect on biofouling due to low tolerance of bacteria at high temperature. For many bacteria, the optimum temperature for their growth is about 40 °C [66]. A slight increase in temperature would result in substantial changes in the growth of biofilms as the microbial activity is very sensitive to temperature [67]. For instance, a study has shown that biofilm thickness of Escherichia coli increased by 80% by increasing the temperature from 30 to 35 °C [68]. However, in the case of Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, more formation of biofilm was observed at 32 °C than those of higher (37 °C) and lower temperature (18 °C) [69]. This suggests that the initial interaction between the bacteria andmembrane surfacemight be varied, depending on the types of targeted bacteria and the applied operating temperature.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Effect of pH
sections.text:
pH is generally known to have significant impact on the bacteria growth and attachment on the membrane surface. Olson [70] reported that bacteria responded to the internal and external pH changes by adjusting the activity and synthesis of proteins associated with many different cellular processes. Li et al. [71] have shown that the steady increase in acidity could increase the possibility of cell survival in comparison to the sudden increase by rapid addition of hydrochloric acid. This implies that bacteria contain mechanisms that allow them to adapt to the small environmental changes in pH. Yet, there are cellular processes that do not become accustomed to pH variations so easily. The optimum pH for extracellular polysaccharide (EPS) production depends on the individual species, but for most bacteria, it normally falls at around pH 7 [71].

sections.heading: 3.1.3. Effect of pressure
sections.text:
As reported by Kwan et al. [72], the hydraulic pressure (RO) and osmotic pressure (FO) have significant effects on the biofilm dimension. In RO systems, hydraulic pressure (ΔP) is applied on the feed side to produce permeate water flux through the semi-permeable membrane. This application of ΔP causes bacteria in the feed solution to be deposited and subsequently compacted on the membrane, thus affecting permeate water flux behavior. Biofilm compaction tends to hinder membrane water flux via two co-occurring factors. First, it is possible that biofilm enhances osmotic pressure due to increased accumulation of solutes in the compacted biofilms at themembrane surface compared to looser ones (see Fig. 5). Second, the biofilm hydraulic resistance increases primarily due to the compaction of the extracellular polymeric substances (EPS)—hydrogel.
In FO systems, the osmotic pressure difference (Δπ) draws water from feed solution across the semi-permeable membrane. As no ΔP is applied in FO, no biofilm compaction occurs. It is suggested that hydraulic resistance in the thicker FO biofilm is negligible due to its loose conformation. Moreover, the sparse and channeled FO biofilm structure could account for enhanced back diffusion of the solutes to the bulk solution, thus lessening concentration polarization within the biofilm.
As shown in Table 2 and Fig. 6, the live and dead biofilm components developed in FOwere both significantly larger than RO, as evidenced by their respective total biovolumes of 71 ± 10 and 44 ± 5 μm3/μm2, respectively. It can be noted that the total biovolumes were calculated as the sum of live, dead, and polysaccharide–EPS biovolumes. Live to dead cell biovolume ratios for FO and RO (0.72 and 0.52, respectively) shed light on the viability of the biofilm. Thus, it was found that a similar number of live and dead cells were present in the FO biofilm, while significantlymore dead cells were present in RO (Table 2) as a result of the compact cell configuration in the RO biofilms.

As discussed in the previous studies [73–76], an increase in flow velocity resulted in an increase in bacterial number of biofilms. This can be attributed to better mass transfer of growth limiting nutrients at the higher flow velocity of water [74,76]. Nevertheless, the thickness of biofilms depends on the flow velocity of the water. At high velocity, the thickness decreases due to the generation of turbulent flow at surrounding area. Studies regarding thehydrodynamic of aqueousmedium showed that the flow velocity adjacent to the substratum and liquid interface is negligible. The biofilm thickness depends on the flow velocity [73]. Simoes et al. [75] studied the differences between three strains of

sections.heading: 3.1.5. Hydrophilic/hydrophobic surface properties
sections.text:
It is commonly known that the membranes with hydrophilic surfaces are less susceptible to fouling caused by organic substances and microorganisms due to a decrease of the interaction between the foulant and the membrane surface. Kochkodan et al. [77] reported that the adhesiveness of E. coli, Pseudomonas putida or Acinetobacter calcoaceticusmicroorganisms to different polymer membranes (polyethersulfone (PES, denoted as P005), polystyrene (PS, denoted as PS100) and cellulose (C100)) were essentially correlated with
hydrophobic/hydrophilic properties of both the cells and membranes. In terms of hydrophilicity, E. coli cells are more hydrophilic comparing with A. calcoaceticus or P. putida. On the other hand, PES and PSF membranes are more hydrophobic than cellulose. As can be seen from Fig. 7, more P. putida cells were attached on membrane surface compared to other types of cells. The findings suggested that hydrophobic interactions between the bacterial cell and the membrane surface play an important role in the adhesion of microorganisms to the membranes surface.

sections.heading: 3.1.7. Surface roughness
sections.text: Previous studies have shown that membrane surface roughness could affect bacterial attachment in two primary ways. Firstly, the rough surface creates the area of low shear and the removal of attached bacteria is significantly reduced. Secondly, the increased surface area makes more room available for cells to attach and result in thicker biofilm layer [2,80]. Pasmore et al. [79] demonstrated a slight increase in biofilm accumulation on the membrane with increasing roughness of themembrane surface. Prakash et al. [81] investigated the effect of substratumand found that the extent ofmicrobial colonization increased as the surface roughness increased. These findings showed that surface roughness and zeta potential play a dominant role in enhancing the antibacterial activity.

sections.heading: 3.2. Development of low-biofouling membrane with antimicrobial nanoparticles
sections.text:
Themodification of TFCmembrane by imparting antibacterial materials is a promising approach to enhance antimicrobial activity of the membrane, as shown in Table 3. The antibacterial TFC membrane can be prepared by directly coating or depositing inorganic particles onto themembrane surface, whichwas reported to have larger active surface area and higher membrane performance as compared to that of direct blending nanomaterials into the TFC membrane [82]. The earliest mention of the anti-biofouling membrane was disclosed by Kwak et al. [83] and Kim et al. [84] inwhich TiO2was immobilized onto the surface of PA layer of RO membrane. It was found that under UV illumination, the

TiO2 self-assembled hybrid membrane possessed a remarkably higher photocatalytic bactericidal efficiency than that without illumination and the neat TFC membranes. Besides TiO2 nanoparticles, other metals such as Ag, Cu, Ca andMgwere also used as different forms of inorganic antimicrobial agents [85–87]. Karkhanechi et al. [87] recently reported that the antibacterial property of RO membrane surface was improved by the deposition of Cu(OH)2 particles that released Cu ions. On the other hand, Ben-Sasson et al. [88] dip-coated the pristine TFC membrane in the Cu-nanoparticle (Cu-NP) suspension, The functionalization with Cu-NP resulted in tremendously decreased number of viable bacteria attached to the TFC RO membrane by 87%, 96% and 79.5% for E. coli, P. aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus, respectively, after 1-h contact relative to the control membrane.
Compared to other nanomaterials, silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) exhibit excellent antibacterial action and low cytotoxicity to human cells, making them applicable to biomedical and clinical fields [89,90]. Owing to the positive features of Ag-based compounds, AgNPs have been widely incorporated onto the surface of the TFC PA layer to enhance the biofouling resistance and antibacterial activity. Effort has been devoted to develop more effective methods to immobilize AgNPs into the membrane sublayer or graft them onto membrane surface through covalent bond formation. Lee et al. [91] and Kim et al. [92] immobilized AgNPs into the PA thin film layer to improve antifouling properties of the resultant TFC membrane. On the other hand, Yin et al. [93] studied the antibacterial properties of AgNPs incorporated TFCmembrane thatwas covalently bondedwith cysteamine as bridging agent. It was observed that AgNPs grafted TFC membrane was toxic to E. coli as no bacterial growth was observed on the membrane surface. The antimicrobial properties of AgNPs can be explained by the disruption of metabolism of bacterial cells. The action of Ag+ ions on those bacteria is based on the inactivation of membrane proteins followed by the binding with the bacterial DNA to disrupt DNA replication. These mechanisms finally lead to inactivation of the cytochrome b and bactericidal activity (see Fig. 8) [94].
Recently, Rahaman et al. [95] developed novel surface coating functionalized with AgNPs and antifouling polymer brushes via polyelectrolyte layer-by-layer (LBL) self-assembly. It was found that the TFC membranes coated with LBL films of poly (acrylic acid) (PAA)/Ag– polyethylenimine (PEI) achieved over 95% inactivation of bacteria attached to the surface within 1 h of contact time. Moreover, Tang et al. [96] studied the antimicrobial and bacterial anti-adhesive properties of polysulfone membranes modified with AgNPs and polyelectrolyte multilayers. In comparison to the unmodifiedmembranes, the bacterial deposition kinetics on all the modified membranes were reduced by 50% and the bacterial removal efficiencies were significantly increased up to 90%. Carbon-based nanomaterials such as CNTs and graphene have been introduced as an alternative strategy since they have been demonstrated to inactivate bacteria upon contact with bacterial cells [104,105]. The earliest mention of antibacterial activity of single walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) was reported by Kang et al. [104], where likely main mechanism leading to the death of living bacterial is cell membrane damage by direct contact with CNTs. They also further reported that SWNTs displayed higher antibacterial ability that those ofMWNTs. Similar result was shown by Tiraferri et al. [82] where functionalized SWNTs were coated on TFC membrane surface. Their results showed that more than 60% inactivation of bacteria could be achieved within 1-h contact time. On the other hand, a TFCmembrane type was synthesized by Kim et al. [98] using interfacial polymerization where the support layer contained acid-modified MWCNTs and a thin-film layer containing nanosilver (nAg) particles. The study of P. aeruginosa batch test indicated that more than 96% of attached bacteria on n-TFN (10 wt.% nAg) membrane but less than 3% of attached bacteria on the n-TFC (0 wt.% nAg) membrane were dead cells, as shown in Fig. 9. These findings showed that the n-TFN membrane possessed higher antibacterial effects than the TFCmembrane, owing to the incorporation of nAg which could interrupt cell membrane functions and subsequently damage cell protein and its DNA structure [106].
Similar studies were conducted by Gunawan et al. [107] where a polyacrylonitrile hollow fiber membrane was coated with Ag/MWNTs hybrid. It was also observed that the presence of Ag/MWNTs disinfection layer effectively inhibited the growth of bacteria in the filtration module and prevented the formation of biofilm on the surface of the

The antimicrobial properties of the PA–CNT– PVA membrane were further studied by the cell viability test. As illustrated in Fig. 10, the cell viability of the PA–CNT–PVA membrane was found to be less than 1%, while those of PA, PA–PVA and commercial RO membranes were larger than 80%.
Compared to CNTs, graphene-based films allow water to permeate through the surface with selectively rejecting other substances, due to the formation of unique two-dimensional nanochannels between these restacked sheets. Recently, functionalization of GO on the active layer TFC membrane has been intensively studied by several researchers due to its enhanced permeability, strongmechanical strength and excellent antimicrobial properties [108,109]. The embedded GO could inactivate bacteria by inducingmembrane damage through physical disruption, charge transfer, formation of reactive oxygen species, and extraction of lipid from the cell on the membrane surface [19]. Perreault et al. [101] observed the reduction of E. coli cells up to 64.5% after direct contact with the GO-TFC membrane for 1 h (as shown in Fig. 11(A)). This result was further supported by SEM analysis, where most cells attached on GO-functionalized TFC membrane appeared to be flattened or shrunk (see Fig. 11(C) and (D)) as compared with cells attached on the control TFC membrane (see Fig. 11(B)). The recent study conducted by Chae et al. [110] also showed that the biovolume of cells attached on the membrane was decreased by approximately 98% with the addition of GO into the PA layer, which can be attributed to the excellent hydrophilicity, negative charge and high surface smoothness. Furthermore, Sun. et al. [103] developed an antibiofouling membrane by in situ fabrication of GO–AgNPs onto cellulose acetate (CA) membranes. The improvement was mainly due to synergistic effect of GO and AgNPs, where GO nanosheets trap the bacteria and the AgNPs pierce the bacterial cell wall, resulting in the leakage of cellular constituents and accelerating bacterial cell death. sections.heading: 4. Challenges in anti-bacterial and low scaling TFC membrane development
sections.text:
The excitement and great benefits harnessed from the nanomaterials on anti-fouling ability of TFC membrane have spurred great
Please cite this article as: C.S. Ong, et al., Nanomaterials for biofouling and lination (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.desal.2016.01.007
interest in desalination industry sectors. To ensure that these innovative nano-enabling technologies are going to flourish and expand, several key technical constraints ranging from economic feasibility to synthesis process have to be addressed. Economic feasibility seems to be themost challenging and thus should be given more attention in terms of research for new approaches and preparation techniques. The incorporation of different nanoparticles into TFC membranes are also facing scaling up issues due to the complexity of operation and maintenance consideration. The long-term stability, membrane reliability, and cost reduction of TFC membranes incorporated with nanomaterials should be further improved to allow for higher applicability to industrial scale. Other challenges include low salt rejection compared to conventional membranes as a result of the fragments of nanomaterials in the TFC membrane that allow for salt penetration and salt rejection reduction [18]. Also, the mechanical strength and durability remain a challenge to address, which might inflict the excellent anti-fouling performance and limited their wide scale application. Moreover, the synthesis of some emerging novel nanomaterials such as MWCNT, GO

In addition, there are still some limitations associatedwith preparation of controllable composite with nanomaterials that have consistent properties such as uniformity of pores, structure, morphology and aspect ratio. For instance, the entangled CNTs and TiO2 into TFC membranes might lead to non-uniform dispersion in the polymer and such fabrication issues must be prioritized for wide scale applications in desalination [113].

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text: The development of new generation of TFCmembranes with the incorporation of nanomaterials can address the environmental impacts posed by current conventional desalination. The nanocomposite membrane that can maintain or perhaps outperform the existing conventional membrane is pivotal for the sustainability of desalination industries. This review focuses on the development of new generation of TFC membrane in the past decade and it is clear that more work and research are focusing on the understanding the dynamics of nanomaterials and their performance in desalination. In the previous discussion, we found that there are many factors that could affect the biofouling and scaling on membrane surface, which range from system operating parameters tomembrane surface properties. Numerous studies have shown thatmembrane surface properties such as hydrophobic/ hydrophilic properties, membrane surface charge (zeta potential) and surface roughness, characteristics of feed solution including ionic strength and pH as well as the system operating conditions including pressure, temperature, flow velocity and concentration polarization, are critical to these fouling phenomena because they determine the interaction between the membrane and the foulants. The surface modification of the PA layer of TFC membrane using different nanoparticles has shown remarkable enhancement to the antifouling properties of unmodified TFC membrane. Despite the significantly greater achievements, there are still some challenges encountered during fabrication process of new generation of TFC membrane. These include membrane long term stability, reliability, economic feasibility, poor dispersion of these nanomaterialswithin the PA layer, lack of chemical interaction between nanomaterials and organic PA layer as well as alignment control of nanotubes in PA layer. Thus, it is necessary to develop more advanced/novel nanomaterials with specific surface properties that could readily disperse well in non-polar solvent and/or to achieve homogenous distribution of the nanomaterials in PA layer. Nevertheless, it is worth to highlight that the development of strong antifouling composite membranes using different nanomaterials to tailor the membrane surface properties while optimizing the operation conditions, feed pre-treatment and cleaningprocess. Undoubtedly,membrane fouling problem can be greatly suppressed to extend the effectiveness and long term performance of the membrane. Overall, it is worth noting that dedicated scientific investigation on TFC antifouling properties has accelerated during the past decade.With ongoing research, it is possible that more advancements and more conclusive findings can be noted in the coming years, especially in the areas of economic and environmental sustainability.
